title: Kimwolf Android botnet infects over 2 million devices
executive_summary: The Kimwolf Android botnet has infected an estimated 2 million Android devices worldwide by exploiting exposed Android Debug Bridge (ADB) services and residential proxy networks, according to cybersecurity researchers.
The botnet provides its operators with capabilities for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, proxy bandwidth resale, and other monetization methods.
what_happened: Cybersecurity firm Synthient reported that the Kimwolf botnet has grown to more than 2 million infected Android devices, primarily through exploiting exposed ADB ports and proxy infrastructure.
The botnet’s spread is tied to residential proxy networks, where vulnerable devices such as Android TV boxes are turned into proxy nodes or compromised after sale.
Kimwolf infections have been observed since at least August 2025, and the botnet has been linked to massive DDoS traffic and proxy resale operations.
who_is_affected: Owners of Android devices with exposed ADB interfaces, such as Android TV set-top boxes and similar hardware.
Networks relying on residential proxy services that may host bot nodes.
Organizations and internet infrastructure providers affected by large-scale botnet-driven attacks.
attack_flow: Attackers identify Android devices with exposed ADB ports.
Devices join the Kimwolf botnet via proxy exploitation.
Compromised devices tunnel traffic, perform proxy forwarding, and accept remote commands.
Operators monetize the botnet through DDoS services and proxy bandwidth resale.
business_impact: Unauthorized use of consumer devices as botnet nodes.
Potential service disruption from large distributed attacks.
Increased operational risk for networks and services targeted by botnet traffic.
Brand reputation issues for proxy providers and device manufacturers.
risk_reason: The combination of exposed Android Debug Bridge services and the abuse of residential proxy networks enables Kimwolf to scale rapidly, evade detection, and launch high-impact operations at internet scale.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Android devices ship with ADB exposed by default or without proper security controls.
Residential proxy networks fail to restrict internal network access and unauthenticated services.
Lack of visibility over IoT-class hardware behavior and network traffic.

immediate: Disable exposed ADB services on all Android devices where not required.
Block traffic from known botnet command-and-control (C2) domains at network boundaries.
short_term: Monitor for unusual outbound traffic patterns indicating botnet participation.
Audit proxy networks for risky exposure configurations.
long_term: Enforce strong device hardening for IoT/Android hardware.
Collaborate with residential proxy providers to identify and mitigate botnet abuse.
Deploy anomaly detection tools to flag malicious or unauthorized device behavior.

what_this_does_not_mean: Every Android device is infected — only those with exposed ADB or insecure configurations are at highest risk.
Kimwolf can automatically compromise fully patched and properly configured systems.

signs: Unexpected proxy or tunneling traffic from endpoints.
Outbound connections to known botnet C2 servers.
alerts: Detection of botnet signatures in network logs.
Elevated unusual traffic volumes matching DDoS patterns.
